article.title: Dissipative particle dynamics simulation of critical pore size in a lipid bilayer membrane

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1(a) shows a 3D view of a simulated membrane with a pore. What fills the space on both sides of the membrane and in the pore?
Figure 1(c) shows a single lipid molecule. How many head particles and tail particles does this lipid have?
choices: 3 head particles, 2 tails composed of 6 particles each
2 head particles, 3 tails composed of 5 particles each
3 head particles, 1 tail composed of 12 particles
1 head particle, 2 tails composed of 6 particles each

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of visual representation is shown in Figure 1(d)?
What trend is observed in the time evolution of membrane pores as depicted in Figure 2?
choices: All pores shrink and seal regardless of their initial size
Pores either shrink and seal or grow exponentially depending on their initial size
All pores grow exponentially regardless of their initial size
Pores remain stable in size regardless of their initial size

multiple_choice_question.text: How many different initial pore sizes (ro) are presented in Figure 2?
What does the shaded region in Figure 3 represent?
choices: The possible range of the critical ratio (rc/h) below which pores seal
The time it takes for a pore to reach its maximum size
The difference in size between the largest and smallest simulated pores

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 3, what is the unit used to measure the size (y-axis)?
Figure 7 compares the time evolution of perforated finite membranes with different lipid tail lengths. What is the main difference in the final state of the membranes?
choices: Both membranes seal their pores and remain as stable finite discs.
The membrane with 6 particles per tail transitions into a layered cluster, while the membrane with 12 particles per tail remains a stable finite disc.
The membrane with 6 particles per tail remains a stable finite disc, while the membrane with 12 particles per tail transitions into a layered cluster.
Both membranes seal their pores but disintegrate completely.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which panels in Figure 7 show both front and internal side views of the membrane?
